metadata.case_name: Dr. Akshaibar Lal & Ors. v. Banaras Hindu University

facts.text: Affairs of Banaras Hindu University deteriorating, requiring immediate intervention.
President of India, as Visitor, appointed Mudaliar Committee to enquire into discipline and suggest reforms.
Mudaliar Committee suggested appointing Screening Committee to review teaching staff appointments and work.
President promulgated Ordinance IV of 1958 amending BHU Act, substituting Statute No. 30 setting up Screening Committee.
Ordinance repealed by BHU Amendment Act, 1958 (XXXIV of 1958), re-enacting Statute No. 30 with Reviewing Committee procedure.

Appellants holding posts: Group I - Dr. Akshaibar Lal (Reader, College of Agriculture, Res. 100), Dr. Gopal Tripathi (Professor Chemical Engg/Principal College of Tech, Res. 101), Pandit Ram Vyas Pandey (Reader/Head Jyotish Sanskrit Mahavidyalaya, Res. 99), Dr. Gauri Shankar Tiwari (Lecturer Chemistry, Res. 102); Group II - Dr. Rain Deo Misra (Professor/Head Botany College of Science, Res. 94), Mr. Ganesh Prasad Singh (Lecturer Physical, Res. 95), Mr. Radhey Shyam Sharma (Lecturer College of Technology, Res. 90), Dr. Ram Yash Roy (Lecturer Botany College of Science, Res. 96). Terminations from June 1, 1960, with 4-6 months pay in lieu of notice.
Solicitor-General referred appellants' cases (except Sharma's pending) to Reviewing Committee.
Reviewing Committee sent findings to University.
For Group I appellants, Executive Council passed Res. 436-439 on Feb 13, 1960, calling show cause why services not terminated based on Reviewing Committee findings.
Group I appellants showed cause on March 5, 1960.
No show cause notices issued to Group II appellants under Statute 30.
Group I filed writ petitions (WP 712-715/1960) on March 9, 1960; ad interim stay by D.S. Mathur J.
High Court modified stay on April 25, 1960 by Jagdish Sahai J., staying proceedings before Executive Council on Reviewing Committee recommendations.
Executive Council Res. 89 on May 15, 1960 postponed consideration of Group I cases till after High Court disposal.
On same day May 15, 1960, passed Res. 90,94-96,99-102 terminating all eight appellants' services from June 1, 1960 under agreements/Ordinance 6.
Appellants filed writ petitions in Allahabad High Court after termination resolutions communicated; dismissed July 15, 1960.
Supreme Court granted special leave; appeals heard.

legal_issues.text: Whether Executive Council could terminate services under agreements or Ordinance No. 6 after invoking procedure under Statute No. 30.
Whether powers under agreements/Ordinances and Statute 30 are cumulative/alternative, allowing switch mid-procedure.
Interpretation of Ordinance No. 6 regarding termination powers.

petitioner_arguments.text: Executive Council could not take recourse to Ordinance No. 6 after starting action under Statute No. 30; Ordinance subordinate to Statute.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Banaras Hindu University Act; Statute No. 30; Ordinance No. 6

petitioner_arguments.text: Action against Group I stayed by High Court and Res. 89; further action under agreements/Ordinance incompetent.
Action mala fide and fraud on University Act and Statute No. 30.

respondent_arguments.text: Executive Council could act under agreements (where existing), Ordinance No. 6 or Statute No. 30 at its option; alternative remedies cumulative.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Agreements; Ordinance No. 6 cl. v; precedents like Shankar Sahai v. Din Dial

court_reasoning.text: Powers of Executive Council derived from Statutes under BHU Act; Ordinances subordinate to Act and Statutes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ordinances subject to Statutes; cannot prevail over them.

court_reasoning.text: Ordinance No. 6 interpreted: power to terminate without cause on 4 months notice/salary in lieu, separate from misconduct etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cl. v allows termination without assigning cause after notice.

court_reasoning.text: Statute No. 30 enacted for special circumstances (continuance detrimental); once invoked and procedure commenced (Solicitor-General, Reviewing Committee), cannot abandon and use general powers under Ordinances/agreements.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Special procedure excludes general powers once started; no cumulative remedies here.

court_reasoning.text: Alternative remedies allowable unless excluded; here Ordinances subordinate, Statute 30 special for detrimental continuance cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Implication clear: cannot switch mid-course; deprives right to show cause.

court_reasoning.text: Cl. 5 of Statute 30 permissive as to action on recommendations but within Statute; duty to complete enquiry purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No discretion to act outside Statute.

court_reasoning.text: Appointing power does not mean dismissal power exercised correctly here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error in assuming cumulative powers post-Statute 30 adoption.

holdings.text: Impugned Resolutions ultra vires as Executive Council could not invoke general powers under agreements/Ordinance 6 after commencing special procedure under Statute 30.
Powers not cumulative in these circumstances; special excludes general once invoked.

precedents_cited.relevance: Alternative remedies can be invoked unless excluded.

precedents_cited.case_name: Om Prakash Gupta v. State of U.P.
State of Madhya Pradesh v. Veereshwar Rao Agnihotry
State of Kerala v. G.M. Francis and Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Where law allows alternative remedies, one or both can be invoked unless excluded expressly or by implication.
Mala fides etc. as examples of ultra vires.

statutes_cited.name: Banaras Hindu University Act, 1915
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of Executive Council, framing Statutes/Ordinances, appointments, contracts.

statutes_cited.name: Banaras Hindu University Amendment Act, 1958 (XXXIV of 1958)
Banaras Hindu University Ordinance IV of 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended Statutes, introduced Screening Committee (repealed but re-enacted).

statutes_cited.name: Statutes of Banaras Hindu University
statutes_cited.relevance: Executive Council powers including appointments; special termination procedure for detrimental continuance.

statutes_cited.name: Ordinances of Banaras Hindu University
statutes_cited.relevance: Termination of service on notice without cause or for misconduct etc.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; Resolutions Nos. 90, 94-96, 99-102 dated May 15, 1960 quashed as ultra vires; writs to issue; respondents to pay costs of appeals and High Court.
outcome.costs: Respondents to pay costs of appeals and High Court.

key_quotes.text: "having invoked Statute No. 30 in the special circumstances and having gone on with that procedure, it was not possible to undo everything and rely upon other powers"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on inability to switch procedures.

key_quotes.text: "The University could not, having started enquiries under Statute No. 30, abandon the enquiries in midcourse and pass on to something else."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains exclusion of general powers once special invoked.

key_quotes.text: "the impugned Resolutions were ultra vires and should be quashed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
